image.altText: Images of Jeremy Rockliff, Rebecca White and Rosalie Woodruff set against a white background.

props.synopsis: Trust in those in government may be falling, but it doesn't mean Tasmanian voters aren't engaging in politics.

title.children: Feeling a bit uninspired by Tasmanian state politics? You're not alone

image.altText: A composite of Jeremy Rockliff sitting in the house of assembly folding his arms and Rebecca White looking off.

props.synopsis: Tasmanians will go to the polls in March in the dark about who donated to the major political parties, with one independent MP saying voters will "have no idea who may have bought influence".

title.children: Money talks, but Tasmanians — yet again — aren't allowed to know who is paying

image.altText: A vector illustration of blue, red and grey lines laid over spherical glowing 3D world map on plain black background.

props.synopsis: The internet powers almost every aspect of our modern life and is key for governments, intelligence agencies, and banks – and there's a worldwide struggle for control happening under the radar and under the waves.

title.children: China and the US are wrestling over a web of cables we never see, but rely on every day

image.altText: People walk through the Chadstone Shopping Centre

props.synopsis: Australia's economy "limps along", but the "tepid" GDP growth at the end of 2023 again fails to keep up with a booming population, extending a deep per capita recession.

title.children: 'Unnecessary rate hike' plunges Australia's economy deeper into per capita recession

image.altText: Nikki Haley clicks her fingers while speaking into a microphone

props.synopsis: Republican challenger Nikki Haley is holding onto hope of a victory in Vermont, while Donald Trump and Joe Biden dominate the Super Tuesday primaries to decide who will run at the US presidential election in November. Follow live.

title.children: Haley jostling for lead in Vermont while Biden and Trump dominate Super Tuesday results

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Biden and Trump win big in Texas
So far there's only one nailbiter: Vermont

image.altText: Parachutes are seen low over the skyline of a city

props.synopsis: The US decision to start parachuting aid into the besieged Palestinian territory has many figures in the humanitarian and diplomatic sector deeply frustrated, writes Eric Tlozek.

title.children: Bombs and bread drop into Gaza, and the US has a hand in both

image.altText: a person's face infront of a screen showing bitcoin record

props.synopsis: Crypto enthusiasts are celebrating, while cynics are describing this as the latest crash and burn cycle of a "zombie" asset that won't die.

title.children: Zombie or saviour? Bitcoin hits a fresh record high, before the 'very volatile' asset plunges again

image.altText: Simiona Tuteru walks outside a courtroom, wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: A trucking boss avoids a prison term, despite allowing a drug-affected driver to get behind the wheel in the lead-up to Melbourne's Eastern Freeway tragedy where four police officers were killed.

title.children: No prison for trucking boss charged over 2020 crash that killed four Victorian police officers

image.altText: Colourful illustrations of five beautiful women. All wear either a dupatta, chador, niqab, khimar or jilbab

props.synopsis: For Muslim women, wearing the hijab can bring a sense of pride, but it can also attract racism as misconceptions and assumptions prevail. So, let's set the record straight.

title.children: The question Muslim women dread every summer

image.altText: Escalators at Carindale shopping centre busy with Christmas shoppers

props.synopsis: Whatever today's economic data shows about how close Australia is to recession the truth is we are already experiencing the biggest dive in living standards in half a century — and have been for two years, writes Peter Martin.

title.children: We're experiencing the biggest dive in living standards in half a century — and a recession is looming

image.altText: Young baby at Childcare, Queenstown

props.synopsis: A childcare centre practice colloquially known as "under the roof" to calculate the ratio of educators to children is being misused in childcare centres, according to respondents of an investigation by 7.30.

title.children: 'Illegally operating every day': Here's what educators have told us about 'under the roof' ratio misuse

image.altText: A sign reads 'BEAUMARIS PRIMARY SCHOOL' behind gum leaves.

props.synopsis: A Board of Inquiry into historical child sexual abuse at Beaumaris Primary School and 23 other schools has recommended the Victorian government formally apologise to victim-survivors. The inquiry revealed one paedophile teacher was linked to the abuse of 60 individuals.

title.children: Victorian child sexual abuse schools inquiry finds teacher linked to abuse of 60 individuals

image.altText: The tail of a Qantas plane in front of a Qantas shed on a tarmac at an airport.

props.synopsis: A NSW District Court judge rules that Qantas acted illegally when it sidelined an employee after he raised safety concerns about COVID-19.

title.children: 'Heads have to roll': Senator calls for Qantas board resignations over worker court case

image.altText: a cricket match where an ad for parimatch is visible as a virtual billboard

props.synopsis: The federal communications watchdog examines whether Foxtel breached gambling laws by broadcasting ads for two illegal offshore betting companies during a test cricket match between Australia and New Zealand.

title.children: Foxtel under fire for broadcasting ads for illegal offshore betting companies

image.altText: Australia's Sam Kerr waves up at the crowd in the stands after a Matildas game.

props.synopsis: Lawyers for Matildas captain Sam Kerr, who's accused of the racially aggravated harassment of a police officer in London, are attempting to have the charge dismissed and avoid a criminal trial next year.

title.children: Sam Kerr's legal team make bid to have criminal charge thrown out

image.altText: optus 'yes' sign on glass fronted office block

props.synopsis: Optus has been fined $1.5 million after the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) found it left customers at risk.

title.children: Optus fined $1.5 million for public safety breaches, customers 'at risk'

image.altText: A person gets a vaccination in their right arm by a nurse.

props.synopsis: A 62-year-old man from Germany, who reportedly got more than 200 COVID shots for "private reasons", has become the focus of new research into the effects of excessive immunisation on the human body.

title.children: A 62-year-old German man received 217 COVID shots in the space of 29 months

image.altText: A group of office workers standing at the corner of an intersection in a city waiting to cross.

props.synopsis: Australia's economy grew by a modest 0.2 per cent in the December quarter, while the ASX is trading lower after a fall on Wall Street following bitcoin plunging hours after setting a record high. Follow live.

title.children: What do today's GDP numbers tell us about the economy and where we're headed? We're answering your questions

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Superannuation returns continue their advance in February
Wondering what the GDP figures tell us about the economy?
Australia's economy grew by 0.2pc in December quarter

image.altText: a woman wiht red hair in black clothes and clothes arranges the white shirt on a manequin

props.synopsis: Costumes worn by Drew Barrymore and Kate Winslet were also sold for thousands of dollars.

title.children: Colin Firth's Mr Darcy shirt makes a splash at auction, selling for $38,000

image.altText: A woman with a neutral expression standing in front of a flowering bush.

props.synopsis: It's taken Dassi Erlich a long time to stop blaming herself for the sexual abuse perpetrated by her former school principal, Malka Leifer. But the support of her family has helped her find strength.

title.children: She grew up in a sect where women couldn't be loud, but Dassi Erlich found the strength to bring down her abuser

image.altText: A red-lid household rubbish bin on a suburban front verge with a yellow-lid bin behind it.

props.synopsis: Kerbside rubbish will become a commodity when the project in the Latrobe Valley gets underway, but an environmental group has concerns about the impact.

title.children: Household rubbish to be burnt for electricity at Victoria's first waste-to-energy plant

image.altText: A man in lifesaving gear carries a limp child from the ocean as another lifesaver looks on.

props.synopsis: Lifesavers say "if we can't see you, we can't save you" after a summer of worrying trends and almost 100 drownings, most outside patrolled beach areas or in remote locations.

title.children: Selfie culture, poor swimming skills behind rise in summer drownings, water safety experts say

image.altText: A mum hugs her three children in a driveway.

props.synopsis: Queensland pledged to criminalise coercive behaviour after the murder of Hannah Clarke and her three children. The move will be closely watched by other jurisdictions.

title.children: Queensland is about to become the second jurisdiction in Australia to criminalise coercive control

image.altText: A young woman with brown hair folds washing while on her phone and sitting at a home office desk.

props.synopsis: Using micro-breaks to stay on top of domestic chores when working from home not only improves your work-life balance, it can also help boost your productivity and focus.

title.children: Why doing little chores while WFH is actually good for you

image.altText: Photo of murdered Lake Macquarie woman Carly McBride

props.synopsis: A man who killed a woman eight weeks after meeting her at a Central Coast drug rehabilitation centre has had his bid for freedom rejected.

title.children: Mixed martial arts fighter loses appeal against 27-year jail sentence for killing his girlfriend

image.altText: a young man with dark facial hair wearing a blue collared shirt

props.synopsis: Northern Territory Police Minister Brent Potter says the posts, which he shared up to a decade ago, are not reflective of his current views. It comes amid an ongoing review into racism within the NT Police Force.

title.children: NT police minister says Facebook posts, one quoting Nazi general, are 'cynical and satirical humour'

image.altText: A film still of Mia McKenna-Bruce, smiling slightly as she lies on a pool chair, a balloon in her hands.

props.synopsis: Director Molly Manning Walker's debut film doesn't shy away from the hard questions about sex and consent.

title.children: How to Have Sex is not an instruction guide but will teach teenagers vital lessons about sex

image.altText: A man stands in front of wall with Julalikari logo

props.synopsis: A financial report published by the Office of the Registrar of Indigenous Corporations reveals Sam Ashton was stood down in March 2023 as a result of an investigation by independent legal representatives and financial advisors.

title.children: Former Aboriginal corporation CEO stood down after $1.2 million in financial irregularities discovered

image.altText: two women on stage

props.synopsis: The weight-loss journey of a movie star, who dropped an astonishing 50 kilograms in a year, captivates people across China.

title.children: Actress drops 50kgs for Chinese film hit You Only Live Once

image.altText: A group of long-stemmed wine glasses containing red wine being clinked together in a "cheers" salute.

props.synopsis: With the equivalent of more than 860 Olympic swimming pools worth of wine in storage and growers being paid 1970s prices for grapes, the industry is in a crisis bordering on catastrophe.

title.children: Nothing to cheer, as 2-billion-litre glut of red wine sparks calls for halt on new vine plantings

image.altText: Black-and-white image of a swimming pool with people in Sydney Harbour.

props.synopsis: Billions of dollars need to be spent on repairing and replacing around 500 public pools over the next decade, so what does the future hold for the much-loved sporting and social hubs?

title.children: Australians are champion swimmers, but the pools they train in are closing
